description: From Latin quādrīgae, literally "four yoked", from quattuor (“four”) + iugum (“yoke”).

entries.meaning: (historical) A Roman racing chariot drawn by four horses abreast.
examples: In the Vatican Library is a vase of terra cotta, on whose upper part we see delineated the sun and moon, in a quadriga, which proceeds forward [travels, voyages, fulfils its course] upon a ship.  […]  Both these deities stand in a quadriga, which indeed is the vehicle proper to the sun, insomuch that the Rhodians every year threw into the sea a quadriga, dedicated to this divinity.

entries.meaning: (historical) A team of four horses, or sometimes other animals, especially as used in chariot racing.
